title: Critical Thinking & Decision Making
subtitle: The Foundation
description: Learn to evaluate information, resist manipulation, and think independently. This module helps you develop the ability to analyze claims, identify biases, and make evidence-based decisions in the face of social pressure and misinformation.
completionMessage: You have learned how to evaluate information, resist manipulation, and think independently. These critical thinking skills form the cognitive foundation for all the other modules. You can now analyze claims, identify biases, and make evidence-based decisions even in the face of social pressure and misinformation.

questions.title: The Viral Health Claim
questions.scenario: Your college classmate shares a viral social media post claiming that eating local honey from your village can prevent COVID-19. The post includes testimonials from villagers and has been shared thousands of times. Your family members are excited to buy expensive local honey based on this claim.
questions.question: What is your best approach?

options.text: Ignore the claim since social media posts are always fake
options.feedback: While skepticism is healthy, dismissing all social media without evaluation is also not critical thinking. Some social media can contain accurate information from credible sources.

options.text: Support buying the honey since many villagers have shared positive testimonials
options.feedback: Personal testimonials, no matter how numerous, are not scientific evidence. This represents anecdotal evidence which can be misleading and doesn't establish causation.

options.text: Research scientific evidence about honey and COVID-19 before making any decision
options.feedback: This demonstrates critical thinking by seeking evidence-based information before making health-related decisions. Scientific research and credible health authorities should guide health choices.

options.text: Buy the honey anyway since it's from your village and won't cause harm
options.feedback: Even 'harmless' remedies can be problematic if they create false security or delay proper medical care. Cost and opportunity considerations also matter.

questions.title: The Climate Change Debate
questions.scenario: During a class debate about climate change, your professor presents data showing rising temperatures in Nepal. Another student argues that since it was cold last winter in Kathmandu, global warming must be false. Most students seem to agree with this counterargument.
questions.question: How should you respond?

options.text: Stay quiet to avoid conflict with your classmates
options.feedback: While avoiding conflict may seem safer, staying silent when you understand the evidence fails to contribute to meaningful academic discourse.

options.text: Argue that professors are always right and students should accept their data
options.feedback: Appeal to authority without understanding the reasoning is not critical thinking, even when the authority is correct.

options.text: Distinguish between weather patterns and long-term climate trends using evidence
options.feedback: This demonstrates understanding of the difference between weather and climate, and reliance on systematic data rather than isolated examples.

options.text: Agree with the majority since they seem convinced by the winter example
options.feedback: This shows susceptibility to groupthink and confuses anecdotal local weather with global climate patterns. Majority opinion doesn't determine scientific accuracy.

questions.title: Political Corruption Article
questions.scenario: You read a news article claiming that a specific political party is entirely responsible for Nepal's corruption problems. The article cites several recent corruption cases involving politicians from that party, but doesn't mention any cases involving other parties.
questions.question: What is your most critical response?

options.text: Look for additional sources that provide broader context about corruption across parties
options.feedback: This seeks comprehensive information and recognizes that selective reporting can create misleading impressions about complex issues.

options.text: Share the article immediately since it provides specific examples of corruption
options.feedback: Sharing without verification spreads potentially misleading information. Cherry-picked examples don't represent the full picture.

options.text: Dismiss the article since all political news is biased
options.feedback: Complete dismissal prevents you from gathering any useful information. Some political reporting is credible and important.

options.text: Believe the article since it provides concrete examples and evidence
options.feedback: Having examples doesn't make an argument complete or unbiased. Selective evidence can be misleading.

questions.title: Education vs. Experience Debate
questions.scenario: Your friend claims that memorizing textbook content is useless for real-world success and that only practical experience matters. They use examples of successful entrepreneurs who dropped out of school to support their argument.
questions.question: How do you evaluate this claim?

options.text: Ask other friends what they think to get a consensus opinion
options.feedback: Seeking consensus without analysis doesn't develop your own critical evaluation abilities.

options.text: Agree completely since practical experience is obviously more important than books
options.feedback: This oversimplifies complex factors that contribute to success and ignores the value of foundational knowledge and critical thinking skills.

options.text: Disagree completely since education is always necessary for success
options.feedback: This is equally oversimplified and ignores the reality that different paths can lead to different types of success.

options.text: Analyze both the benefits of formal education and practical experience for different goals
options.feedback: This recognizes that different types of knowledge and experience serve different purposes, and success depends on multiple factors.

questions.title: Conflicting Career Information
questions.scenario: You're researching career options and find conflicting information online. One source says data science has excellent job prospects in Nepal, while another says the field is oversaturated. Both sources appear professional and well-designed.
questions.question: What's your best approach to resolve this contradiction?

options.text: Assume both sources are wrong since they contradict each other
options.feedback: Contradictory sources don't mean both are wrong; they may reflect different aspects, time periods, or regions.

options.text: Ask your parents which source seems more trustworthy
options.feedback: While parents may have wisdom, they may not have current expertise in evaluating technical career information.

options.text: Evaluate the credibility, recency, and methodology of both sources
options.feedback: This systematic approach to evaluating sources considers multiple factors that affect information quality and reliability.

options.text: Choose the source that tells you what you want to hear about data science
options.feedback: Confirmation bias leads to poor decisions by filtering information based on preferences rather than accuracy.

questions.title: The Viral Video
questions.scenario: A short video circulates on TikTok showing a well-known Nepali public figure 'admitting' they took money for a decision. The clip is low-quality, heavily shared, and people in your circle are already calling for punishment.
questions.question: What is your most critical first step?

options.text: Dismiss it automatically because all online videos are fake
options.feedback: Healthy skepticism should still include investigation; some online content is authentic.

options.text: Check whether reputable outlets or official sources have verified the clip, and look for signs of manipulation
options.feedback: This applies evidence-based verification: cross-checking, source checking, and manipulation awareness.

options.text: Share it to raise awareness before it gets deleted
options.feedback: Sharing first spreads potential misinformation and can harm innocent people before verification.

options.text: Assume it is true because many people are sharing it
options.feedback: Popularity is not proof; virality can be driven by emotion, not accuracy.

questions.title: Scholarship Scam Alert
questions.scenario: Your friend forwards a message claiming a 'new rule' will immediately cancel all scholarships unless students submit personal details through a random link. The message warns: 'Do it today or you'll lose your chance.'
questions.question: What is your best decision-making approach?

options.text: Ignore it completely without checking, because messages like this are always scams
options.feedback: It may be a scam, but not checking could make you miss real deadlines; verification is better.

options.text: Ask a group chat what everyone else is doing and follow the majority
options.feedback: Group responses can be wrong; consensus is not evidence.

options.text: Verify through official scholarship/university channels before taking any action
options.feedback: This protects you by validating the claim through authoritative channels.

options.text: Fill it out quickly because the risk of missing out is too high
options.feedback: Urgency is a common manipulation tactic; acting fast can lead to fraud or data theft.

questions.title: Antibiotic Misuse
questions.scenario: A popular Instagram page claims that 'antibiotics cure most fevers in 24 hours,' and people in your neighborhood start buying antibiotics without prescriptions whenever someone gets sick.
questions.question: What is the most critical response?

options.text: Recommend using antibiotics early 'just in case'
options.feedback: 'Just in case' antibiotic use is a major driver of antimicrobial resistance and side effects.

options.text: Look for credible medical guidance and explain why misuse can be harmful
options.feedback: This combines evidence-checking with responsible communication.

options.text: Say nothing because medical topics are too complicated to discuss
options.feedback: Silence allows misinformation-driven behavior to spread unchecked.

options.text: Support it because antibiotics are common and usually work
options.feedback: Many fevers are viral; antibiotics don't treat viruses and misuse increases resistance risk.

questions.title: Comparing News Sites
questions.scenario: Two news sites report opposite conclusions about the same policy. Site A is polished and emotional; Site B is plain-looking but cites documents and data. Your friends say, 'The professional-looking one must be more reliable.'
questions.question: What is your best evaluation method?

options.text: Avoid both because disagreement means both are unreliable
options.feedback: Conflicting reports require deeper evaluation, not total avoidance.

options.text: Trust Site B because unpopular sources are usually more honest
options.feedback: Being 'underground' doesn't guarantee accuracy; evidence still matters.

options.text: Compare evidence quality: sources, documents, methods, and whether claims can be independently checked
options.feedback: This focuses on verifiability and evidence strength rather than style.

options.text: Trust Site A because presentation quality signals credibility
options.feedback: Design can be used to persuade; it is not evidence.

questions.title: The Migration Poll
questions.scenario: You read a post claiming '90% of young people in Nepal want to leave the country,' based on a poll from one private college in Kathmandu. The post treats it as a national fact.
questions.question: What is the most critical interpretation?

options.text: Share it because it 'feels true' based on your own experience
options.feedback: Personal experience is limited and can reinforce confirmation bias.

options.text: Accept it since the number is specific and sounds researched
options.feedback: Specific numbers can still come from weak methods or biased samples.

options.text: Reject it because all polls are manipulation
options.feedback: Some polls are rigorous; blanket rejection prevents learning from data.

options.text: Question sampling and representativeness before treating it as a national conclusion
options.feedback: This recognizes that who was surveyed matters as much as the result.
